item.title: A Lisp in a CTF! - 0xL4ugh CTF 2024
item.description:
Hi there, and welcome to this new video!

Today we will analyze a challenge taken from the 0xL4ugh CTF 2024.

The challenge consists in analyzing the code of a Clojure application in order to find an authentication bypass and an improper input validation. The vulnerabilities were pretty simple, however the application was written in Clojure, a member of the loved Lisp family of languages. This made the challenge fun!

As always, I hope you find the video helpful, and I would appreciate if you leave your feedback down in the comments, and share this series with like-minded people.

Thank you very much!

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Introduction
00:50 Analyzing project structure
03:40 Reading Clojure code
15:50 Finding the Authentication Bypass
20:35 Using Read-time evaluation to obtain flag
27:55 Conclusion

-------------------------

item.title: Extend Burpsuite with your own Custom Extensions!
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

Burpsuite is a powerful tool that allows penetration testers and researchers to analyze the securiy of web applications and of web API endpoints.
One of the most interesting aspect of Burpsuite is that it can be extended by using the exposed Montoya APIs.

In this video I showcase a simple development pipeline that can be used to build your own custom extensions for Burpsuite.
The setup uses Java as a programming language and maven as the build system.

Then, to show how to work with the Montoya APIs, I build two simple yet pratical extensions.
In the future I might build more complex extensions.

If you like the video, please support my work by subscribing to the channel, sharing the video with like-minded people, and keep following for future videos!

Thank you very much!

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Extensions in Burpsuite
02:50 Setup the development pipeline
08:10 Loading our first extension
13:15 Exploring Montoya APIs
17:45 Sample Extension #1 - Hello World
20:40 Sample Extension #2 - ContextMenuItemsProvider
27:10 Practical Extension #1 - Repeater Rename Tabs
33:40 Practical Extension #2 - Copy2Org
40:00 Conclusion

-------------------------

REFERENCES

- Material: https://github.com/LeonardoE95/yt-en/tree/main/src/2025-01-16-tools-burpsuite-extension
- Montoya API: https://portswigger.github.io/burp-extensions-montoya-api/javadoc/burp/api/montoya/MontoyaApi.html
- Montoya API examples: https://github.com/PortSwigger/burp-extensions-montoya-api-examples
- Maven: https://maven.apache.org/

item.title: PHP-CGI RCE via BestFit! - CVE-2024-4577
item.description:
Hi there,

In this video we take a look at CVE-2024-4577, a vulnerability discovered by the joint research of Orange Tsai and splitline.

The vulnerability affects windows OS, and particulary instaces of Apache that support PHP-CGI. It allows attackers to obtain RCE by introducing arbitrary arguments to the executable being called.

The vulnerability makes use of "BestFit", a character conversion mechanism implemented in Windows that handles situation where UTF-16 characters need to be converted into ANSI characters.

Specifically, the vulnerability affect windows OS configuration that run with specific ANSI code pages, such as the Japanese code page. This is because during the attack the UTF-16 payload of the user is transformed into an ANSI bytes, and this transformation depends on the ANSI code page currently running in the system

During the video, the vulnerability is discussed and analyzed, and a vulnerable testbed with a PoC is showcased in order to understand how to exploit the vulnerability.

Thank you for watching, subscribe, share this video with like minded people, and leave some feedback in the comments!

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Introduction
03:00 Reading the Advisory
07:20 Vulnerable testbed and PoC
11:40 Understanding WorstFit
20:25 CVE-2024-4577
23:40 Payload analysis

-------------------------

REFERENCES

- Material: https://github.com/LeonardoE95/yt-en/tree/main/src/2025-01-12-cves-CVE-2024-4577
- Advisory: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/cve-2024-4577
- Blog post from Orange: https://blog.orange.tw/posts/2025-01-worstfit-unveiling-hidden-transformers-in-windows-ansi/

item.title: Exploiting a Blind NoSQL Injection - NiteCTF 2024
item.description:
Hi there, and welcome to this new video!

Today we will analyze a challenge taken from the NiteCTF 2024.
The challenge consists in analzing the code of a NextJS application in order to find a Blind NoSQL Injection.
The injection can be used to obtain the flag and solve the challenge.

During the video I discuss how to define simple objectives for performing a secure code review (SCR) on a codebase and I show, step-by-step, how to construct the payload required to exploit the blind injection.

As always, I hope you find the video helpful, and I would appreciate if you leave your feedback down in the comments, and share this series with like-minded people.

Thank you very much!

-------------------------

item.title: A Sensible Approach to Sponsorships
item.description:
Hi there, and welcome to this new video!

In this video I give my thoughts on sponsorship and on the criteria that I will use in the future of my channel to accept or deny sponsorship.
It is not really a technical video, more so a video to understand how I want to work in this space.

At the end of the video I also talk about Infomaniak, a Swedish

which contacted me for a yearly sponsorship that I accepted, since I consider their service trustworthy and of high quality.
They give me a VPS (4 CPUs, 12 GBs RAM, 250 GB Disk), and in return I have to mention them every now and then.

Discover Infomaniak: https://www.infomaniak.com/en

I will try my best to make the mentions have meaning with respect to the technical content of the video!

Thank you very much!

item.title: A Cheatsheet and A Methodology
item.description:
Hi there, and welcome to this new video in which we continue the "Windows Privilege Escalation" series!

This episode marks the end of the series, and as such I wanted to give you two last things: a cheatsheet and a methdology related to Windows Privilege Escalation. Both the cheatsheet and the methdology do not cover 100% all possible cases, but they lay a solid foundational knowledge that, if acquired, will be useful regardless of the specific windows context.

item.title: Apache Tomcat Race Condition To RCE - CVE-2024-50379
item.description:
Hi there, hope holiday is going well!

In this quick video we take a look at a recent CVE, which is CVE-2024-50379.
It is a vulnerability in Apache Tomcat, and specifically it is a TOCTOU race condition which can lead to RCE.

It's actually a pretty dangerous vulnerability, given that it allows non authenticated users to execute arbitrary code. To be exploitable, you need to run a vulnerable version of apache tomcat on an operating system such as Windows, that has a case insensitive file system. Finally, you need to enable the readonly=false configuration in the web.xml, allowing users to upload files in the root directory of the server.

In the video we discuss the vulnerability and I showcase a PoC that can be used to exploit it.

Thank you for watching and let me know what you think of these videos where I analyze recently discovered CVEs.

- NIST advisory: https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-50379
- PoC: https://github.com/iSee857/CVE-2024-50379-PoC.git
- Blogpost: https://vulcan.io/blog/how-to-fix-cve-2024-50379/

item.title: AMSI Bypass
item.description:
Hi there, and welcome to this new video in which we continue the "Windows Privilege Escalation" series!

In this episode we look at the Windows Antimalware Scan Interface (AMSI), which is used in the context of Windows to trigger security scans. AMSI provides a standard interface that allows solutions to scan files, memory, and other data for threats. The AMSI bypass technique can be used to disable such mechanism. This, by itself, does not make our payloads evade antivirus directly, but it makes them avoid arising suspicious in the context of well known processes such as powershell. This is just a very tiny and introductory topic within the bigger context of AV/EDR evasion and bypass techniques.

As always, I hope you find the video helpful, and I would appreciate if you leave your feedback down in the comments, and share this series with like-minded people.

Thank you very much!

-------------------------

item.title: Scheduled Tasks
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video we continue the "Windows Privilege Escalation" series.

Specifically, in this video we talk about Scheduled Tasks, a feature of Windows that allows the execution of specific actions, such as PE executable or scripts, when specific conditions are met. These can be time-based conditions, or general trigger conditions such as when the user logs into the system. Given that by design Scheduled Tasks allow for the execution or potentially arbitrary code, they represent an interesting surface attack area if miss-configured.

In the video we discuss what are Scheduled Tasks, how to enumerate, create and delete Scheduled Tasks, and at the end I show a simple exploitation example that showcases the potential threats of having miss-configured Scheduled Tasks in your system.

Ultimately the exploitation of Scheduled Tasks is made hard due to the fact that they cannot be easily enumerated. Still, it is an interesting feature that must be taken into consideration when assessing the security of a Windows system.

As always, I hope you find the video helpful, and I would appreciate if you leave your feedback down in the comments, and share this series with like-minded people.

Thank you very much!

-------------------------

item.title: Stored Credentials and the Windows Vault
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video we continue the "Windows Privilege Escalation" series.

Specifically in this video we analyze the Credential Manager feature, which allows to store and retrieve user credentials. Credentials that are stored within the Credential Manager can be directly used without knowing the user password. This can be dangerous if the user session is compromised.

At the end of the video I introduce the Windows Vault, which is the unerlying storage mechanism that is used by Credential Manager and that uses the Data Protection API (DPAPI) to protect the data with cryptography.

As always, I hope you find the video helpful, and I would appreciate if you leave your feedback down in the comments, and share this series with like-minded people.

Thank you very much!

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Credential Manager
03:30 Using cmdkey
11:50 Windows Vault
14:55 Conclusion

item.title: Windows Hashes
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video we continue the "Windows Privilege Escalation" series.

Specifically, in this video we analyze how hashes are handled in Windows. We discuss the role of hashes, how hashes are used in authentication, and the different types of hashes that are used in Windows.

The focus will be on the LM and NTLM hashes, as well as the Net-NTLMv1 and Net-NTLMv2 hashes. For these hashes we will discuss what is their role, where they can be captured by malicious actors, and how we can crack them using john or hashcat.

As always, I hope you find the video helpful, and I would appreciate if you leave your feedback down in the comments, and share this series with like-minded people.

Thank you very much!

-------------------------

item.title: How Computers Capture Meaning
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video we continue the "Computer Science Foundations" series.
This series is aimed at people who want to build a strong foundational background into computer science, so that later they can choose exactly where to specialize, whether in programming and development, or computer security, or data science, ...

Specifically, in this video we discuss one of the most important concept you will find when interacting with digital technology, which is the idea of encodings.

In this video we will tackle the following question.

What is an encoding?
What does it mean to encode something?
What does it mean to decode something?
What are some basic examples of useful encodings?
What is the social nature of encodings?

I hope you find it helpful, and I would appreciate if you leave your feedback down in the comments, and share this series with like-minded people.

Thank you very much!

-------------------------

01:45 Brief Review
02:40 How do computers capture meaning?

12:32 RFC 20

29:13 The Social Nature of Encodings

-------------------------

item.title: Always Installed Elevated
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video we continue the "Windows Privilege Escalation" series.

Specifically, in this video we discuss a feature called "Always Installed with Elevated Privileges", which allows to assume the role of SYSTEM during the installation of MSI packages. This feature, obviously, poses significant security risks. In the video we show how to use this feature in order to perform privilege escalation.

I hope you find it helpful, and I would appreciate if you leave your feedback down in the comments, and share this series with like-minded people.

Thank you very much!

item.title: UAC Bypass
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video we continue the "Windows Privilege Escalation" series.

Specifically, in this video we analyze the security mechanism known as User Account Control (UAC), which is used by Microsoft to protect the security boundaries when a user wants to elevate privileges. The UAC mechanism works in conjuction with the Mandatory Integrity Control system (MIC).

In the video I showcase how the different UAC levels work, and a few examples on how they can be bypassed.

I hope you find it helpful, and I would appreciate if you leave your feedback down in the comments, and share this series with like-minded people.

Thank you very much!

-------------------------

item.title: DLL Hijacking
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video we continue the "Windows Privilege Escalation" series.

Specifically, we will analyze an exploitation technique known as "DLL Hijacking". The basic idea is that windows executable use code that is not found within the PE file itself, but is found in library code known Dynamic Link Library files (DLL).

A malicious actor can then try to introduce malicious code, not by overwriting the direct binary itself, but by overwriting the DLL used by the binary. Another technique instead is to introduce a new malicious DLL and to hijack the default search order used by Windows in order to load the malicious code.

I hope you find it helpful, and I would appreciate if you leave your feedback down in the comments, and share this series with like-minded people.

Thank you very much!

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Introduction
01:14 Dynamic Link Libraries (DLL)
06:13 A First Example of DLL
14:40 First Technique - Overwriting DLL Binary
22:30 DLL in Services
26:20 Enumerating DLL of a Process
28:20 Finding and Overwriting the DLL of a Service
32:02 Hijacking the DLL Search Order

-------------------------

REFERENCES

item.title: Unquoted Service Path
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video we continue the "Windows Privilege Escalation" series.

Specifically, we will analyze an exploitation technique known as "Unquoted Service Path" which happens when a service binary path contains whitespaces and is not properly quoted. In these scenarios, if the attacker can write into specific folders, it might be possible to hijack the control flow and execute a malicious binary.

I hope you find it helpful, and I would appreciate if you leave your feedback down in the comments, and share this series with like-minded people.

Thank you very much!

item.title: Weak Service Permissions
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video we continue the "Windows Privilege Escalation" series.

Specifically, this video focuses on how we can attack windows services by exploiting weak service permissions. If the service configuration is weakly configured, or we can over-write the binary path of the service, then we can use the service as a means to obtain code execution within the target machine as the user account who is currently executing the service. For system services this will be the administrator account, leading to a privilege escalation.

I hope you find it helpful, and I would appreciate if you leave your feedback down in the comments, and share this series with like-minded people.

Thank you very much!

-------------------------

item.title: Okta Auth Bypass: A Quick Explanation!
item.description:
Hi, and welcome to this video!

Quick video to explain the recent Okta Auth Bypass that happened due to the usage of the bcrypt hashing algorithm. The bcrypt algorithm can only hash up to 72 bytes. If you hash more bytes than that, the bytes after the 72th simply do not matter, which can lead to hash collisions and ultimately to authentication bypasses.

In the Okta case, they hashed a combination of userId, username and password. If a given username had exactly 52 characters or more than that, the combined value with the userId would go over the 72 byte limit of bcrypt and would allow an attacker to authenticate as that user. This happened for the AD/LDAP Del Auth procedure, if the system had previously stored a key within the cache. Thus, it required the victim user to have logged in into the system before the attack could take place.

In the video I show a simple example using nodeJS to showcase the issue.

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP



-------------------------

REFERENCES

- Material: https://github.com/LeonardoE95/yt-en/tree/main/src/2024-11-03-news-okta-auth-bypass
- Okta Security Advisory: https://trust.okta.com/security-advisories/okta-ad-ldap-delegated-authentication-username

item.title: Cross Compilation
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video we continue the "Windows Privilege Escalation" series.

Specifically, in this video we analyze the concept of cross-compilation. We start with a simple review of the idea of compilation, and then we show how to use a cross-compiler to compile in linux binaries that can then be executed on windows. At the end of the video I show how to write a simple reverse shell in C that will run within Windows.

I hope you find it helpful, and I would appreciate if you leave your feedback down in the comments, and share this series with like-minded people.

item.title: Linux Kernel Exploitation
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video we continue the "Linux Privilege Escalation" series.

This time the focus will be on using kernel exploits in order to achieve privilege escalation. This method is not particularly advisable, as it usually creates a lot of noise in the system, and it can even crash the system. However, it is definitely a way to become root in a linux system when the kernel version is vulnerable to known exploits and therefore it is important to consider and be aware of.

Thank you very much!

item.title: Linux Binary Exploitation
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video we continue the "Linux Privilege Escalation" series by discussing the core idea behind binary exploitation and how it can be used to perform privilege escalation.

To build intuition regarding this video, I show a very simple stack-based buffer overflow that will allows us to transform an apparently meaningless program into an arbitrary shell. For the purpose of the video various memory protection mechanism were disabled. However it is important to realize that even modern protections sometimes can be bypassed by skilled enough researchers.

Thank you very much!

item.title: Local Service Exploitation
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video we continue the "Linux Privilege Escalation" series by discussing the idea of exploiting local services, that is, services that are only exposed to local or private network interfaces.

To build intuition on the topic, I bring two examples. In the first we use the Local Port Forwarding technique to access the local service, while in the second we use the Remote Port Forwarding to expose our local service to remote clients.

item.title: Introduction to the GNU Project Debugger (GDB)
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

This video is the first of a series where I will showcase and discuss various tools. Tools are really important in the context of computer science and computer secrity, because most interesting research and results come from people who have mastered the usage of foundational tools.

In this first video I analyze the GNU Project Debugger, also known as GDB. With GDB you can debug any process running in a linux environment. While the tool itself can be limited in certain aspects, it acts as a powerful foundational debugger on top of which you can add extension which adds to feature to the debugger. Later in the video I show one such extension known as Pwndbg.

If you like the video, please support my work by subscribing to the channel, sharing the video with like-minded people, and keep following for future videos!

Thank you very much!

-------------------------

item.title: Scrape Web Data with Python
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video I show how to scrape web data using the Python programming language and the beautifulSoup library. The idea of scraping is simple: you start from an HTML document, and you extract from it only the data you're interested in. This is extremely useful when you only want to focus on specific elements of an HTML page. It can also be useful during penetration testing activities or personal security research.

I hope you find it helpful, and I would appreciate if you leave your feedback down in the comments, subscribe to the channel and share this series with like-minded people.

item.title: Windows Permissions
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video we continue the "Windows Privilege Escalation" series. This time the focus will be on how permissions are handled by the Windows operating system.

We will discuss about the ideas behind authentication, authorization and session managements. Then we discuss the concept of security principals, and how they are identified by Security Identifiers (SIDs). Continuing, we see how to check permissions on files using the icacls.exe command. Finally, we discuss the concepts of Mandatory Integrity Control (MIC) and User Account Control (UAC), which are extra mechanism that are employed by windows to increase the level of security.

I hope you find it helpful, and I would appreciate if you leave your feedback down in the comments, and share this series with like-minded people.

Thank you very much!

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Introduction
01:24 Authentication, Authorization and Session Management
06:45 Security Principals and Security Identifier (SID)
10:05 How to read SIDs
17:41 Enumerate user SIDs
20:40 Access Tokens
24:00 File Permissions with icacls.exe
29:55 Mandatory Integrity Control (MIC)
33:05 User Account Control (UAC)
35:40 Conclusion

-------------------------

REFERENCES

- Material: https://github.com/LeonardoE95/yt-en/tree/main/src/2024-07-06-windows-privesc-windows-permissions

- Well Known SIDs: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/winnt/ne-winnt-well_known_sid_type

item.title: Web Enumeration – DNS Zone Transfer Attacks
item.description:
Hi, and welcome to this new video!

This is the last video of the Web Exploitation series, and in this video we will discuss specifically an attack that can be done to the DNS protocol known as DNS zone transfer attack.

In this video I discuss the differences between virtual hosts, handled by the HTTP protocol, and domain names, handled by the DNS protocol. I then show how to perform a DNS zone transfer attack with the dig command by simulating a vulnerable environment with docker running bind9, an open-source DNS server implementation.

If you have any feedback, please let me know!

item.title: Do you really need a VPN?
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video I want to analyze the following question: "What is the impact on network security of a VPN for the average user?".

Even though most advertisements describe the internet as an inherent unsafe space, in reality this is no longer the case. Even though originally the internet was developed without any sort of protection, as soon as the first e-commerce sites were built and developed the community started immediately to find solutions to the security problems caused by having an insecure communication channel. The result of this effort is the standardization of the TLS protocol (originally it was called SSL).

The latest version of TLS, TLSv1.3, standardized around 2018, represents one of the most secure network protocols ever standardized by humans. It is an achievement that has made the internet a much more secure place. By using TLSv1.3, you can be sure that your communication channel is as secure as it can be, making VPN useless from a point of view of security.

What VPNs marketing fail to communicate is the fact that in a normal interaction between a client and a server there are actually three areas to analyze: the client, the server and the communication channel. The only thing that a VPN would safeguard is the communication channel. However, the security of the communication channel is already handled by the TLS protocol. This means that VPNs do not add a significant improvement to the security of your internet activity. You still have to be careful and not interact with potentially malicious servers, and you also have to take care of making sure your own device is not compromised.

This is not to say that VPN in general have no use-cases. My point is that they do not increase the security of the average person using the internet and the web.

Let me know what you think about the video, and if you are interested in knowing more details regarding TLS, I've already made a video about it, however in the future I can make more in-depth videos discussing how security on the internet of today is achieved.

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Introduction
03:55 Analyzing VPN Marketing Claims
07:02 Beyond the Communication Channel
10:01 On Military Grade Encryption
13:25 Privacy issues
18:15 VPN do not increase security
21:40 Scenario 1: Insecure Channel (HTTP)
27:35 Scenario 2: Secure Channel (TLS + HTTP)
34:40 Towards an honest VPN AD
36:40 How to actually be secure (TLS Certificates)
42:55 Conclusion

-------------------------

REFERENCES

- My video on TLS: https://youtu.be/Wx9h5CkMwdU?si=zSg9CFwN7WVuogzc
- Tom Scott's Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WVDQEoe6ZWY

item.title: Cross Site Scripting (Stored, Reflected and DOM)
item.description:
Hi, and welcome to this new video!

In this video I continue my web exploitation series by discussing another important class of vulnerabilities called Cross-Site Scripting, often abbreviated as XSS. There are three different types of XSS, which are Stored XSS, Reflected XSS and DOM XSS. In this video I will try to give some intuition with respect to all these three different types of XSS.

Given that XSS is a type of client side attack, we will also discuss the ideas behind client side attacks, their different with respect to server side attacks, and why they can be dangerous for the security of a web application.

If you're interested in more videos of the series or if you have any feedback, please let me know!

item.title: Enigma Machine in C – Part 2/3 – Core Implementation
item.description:
Hi, and welcome to this video!

This is the second video of a small series of videos in which I will show how to implement the enigma machine using the C programming language.

The Enigma Machine is an electro-mechanical device that implements an extremely complex substitution cipher. That is, it works by using electricity, but it also has parts that move mechanically. This machine was used by the forces of the Axis during the Second World War in order to protect their communications.

Given that the machine has many different parts, I've decided to split this project into three different videos. In the first one I will give an overview of the machine and I will explain in depth the internals of the machine. In the second video we will implement the core library, and in the third and final video we will implement a simple CLI that will allow us to interface with our enigma machine.

I hope you find the video interesting, and if you have some feedback, please leave it in the comments down below!

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:04:45 Includes, defines and typedefs

00:17:15 Makefile and Compilation

item.title: Pseudo-Randomness – Breaking LCG
item.description:
Hi everyone and welcome to this new video!

In this video I show how to break the Linear Congruential Generator, which is one one of the simplest form of pseudo-random number generators you can use.

Whenever you need to generate unpredictable numbers, remember to not use an LCG, because if you do, an attacker, by extracting few consecutive outputs, can easily predict the successive numbers your generator will output.

-------------------------

28:00 Code to break LCG
29:45 Careful with overflows

item.title: Linux Privilege Escalation – PATH Hijacking
item.description:
Hi and welcome to this new video!

In this video I explained the idea behind PATH hijacking, a common technique for doing privilege escalation in linux machines. During the video I discuss the role of the PATH, and how it can be abused against vulnerable programs to perform privilege escalation.

Now, the same technique also works in windows, because windows also has a PATH variable. So, while in this video I focus on linux, remember that this same attack can work in other OSes, because the concept of the PATH is sort of universal at this point.

If you found the video interesting please support me by subscribing to the channel, and leave any feedback you have in the comments.

-------------------------

item.title: Teaching material
item.description:
The handling of material is a crucial aspect of teaching.

In this video I briefly talk about a solution which I'm trying right now on both my youtube channels (italian and english) in order to manage the material I create for the various videos. The final solution is a git repository that is then uploaded to github. The repository contains a table of videos with useful metadata. Then, for each video, we have a specific folder that contains the material for that video.

The repository is generated semi-automatically using Emacs and org-mode. In the video I briefly discuss how it works behind the scenes. If you are interested in more, please let me know and I will create a more in-depth video about it. The repository discussed is linked in the references.

item.title: Scientific Review – The Impact of Code Patterns on the Security Testing of Web Applications
item.description:
In this video I read a scientific paper that came out last year on the topic of code auditing for web application backend code.
If you are interested in this content, where we analyze in-depth modern scientific research regarding computer security, let me know!

The authors of the paper introduced a novel way of thinking about residual risks when using code analyzers in the context of static application security testing (SAST). In particular, the authors introduced the notion of "testability tarpit" as a specific pattern of code that is known to cause problems for a class of static analysis tools. When these tools analyze a given piece of code, depending on how the code is written, they might find more or less difficulty to follow what is going on in the code in order to detect potential injection vulnerabilities. By analyzing how many such patterns are present in a given codebase, it is possible to gain more awareness on how to interpret the results of the SAST tools used within that same codebase.

The authors focused on the PHP and JavaScript languages, and in particular they

- Created 200+ testability tarpits
- Measured the performance of 11 SAST tools on those patterns of code
- Implemented discovery rules for finding those pattern in the popular Joern framework
- Found new vulnerabilities by performing manual refactoring
- Found new vulnerabilities by performing automatic refactoring

All the work done by the authors is provided within a github project, link in the description.

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Introduction
03:33 Scientific paper structure
05:50 Abstract
13:35 Testability tarpits
26:00 CVE-2011-3357
28:49 Approach overview
36:15 Part 1 – Pattern Creation with SAST tools performance
39:45 Part 2 – Pattern Discovery with Joern
40:26 Part 3 – Pattern Transformation
40:45 Limitations
44:26 Related Work
45:30 Conclusion and Future Work

-------------------------

item.title: Breaking Pseudo-Randomness – On Linear Congruential Generators
item.description:
Recording of the lecture I gave at university (Tor Vergata, Rome) for the Computer Network Security (CNS) course. In the lecture I introduce the idea behind pseudo-randomness and pseudo random number generators in the context of network security and applied cryptography.

-------------------------

01:20:00 Using CSPRNGs

item.title: Introduction to TLS
item.description:
TLS, acronym for Transport Layer Security, is one of the most important network protocol when it comes to protecting the web of today. Introduced in 1995 under the different name of SSL by the Netscape company, TLS has seen a complex and intricate evolution over the years. It was in 1999 when SSL changed its name to TLS, after a re-branding done by the IETF, the institution responsible for standardizing the protocols that make up the internet.

In this video we introduce the main idea behind TLS. In particular we will talk about the core cryptographic services that TLS provides, the big ideas behind the design of the protocol, and we will see a specific pcap trace captured by going to my website using HTTPs, which is HTTP over a TLS session. In future videos I will go in more depth over various topics related to TLS and I will showcase in detail various attacks that were done to TLS.

I hope it is enjoyable to watch, in case let me know and, if you find it interesting, feel free to subscribe to support my project here on youtube.

-------------------------

TIMESTAMP

00:00 Introduction
02:15 The CIA triad
09:50 History of SSL/TLS
15:50 Core ideas in TLS design
20:00 TLS Handshake
27:25 TLS Encryption
33:30 Cipher suites
35:30 Extensions
36:50 Example: PCAP trace
46:35 Attacks to TLS

-------------------------

item.title: OSCP Guide: My Exam Experience
item.description:
The OSCP (Offensive Security Certified Professional) is one of the most sought out certification offered by Offensive Security. In this video I will talk about my exam experience, and in general about the experience that I had while preparing for the certification.

During my preparation I have developed a cheatsheet, which I have made available for anyone at the git repository linked below. I suggest you take a look at it if you're also preparing for the certification.

In the future I will make more videos regarding OSCP and I will enter into more technical details regarding the content taught by the course and the final exam itself.
